docs.title: Home
docs.text:
Welcome to the Max Planck Tandem Group in Holobiont Research!

We are a research group at Universidad Nacional de Colombia focused on advancing knowledge in the mechanisms that determine the diversity patterns of microbial communities of agricultural and livestock systems. Our work combines molecular biology and bioinformatics to address fundamental challenges in microbial ecology.

docs.title: Microbial Diversity in Agricultural Systems
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2023 - Present Funding: [Funding Agency]

Understanding the mechanisms that shape microbial community composition in agricultural soils and their impact on crop health and productivity.

Objectives:

  • Characterize microbial diversity across different agricultural practices
  • Identify key microbial taxa associated with plant health
  • Develop predictive models for community dynamics

Team Members: [Names]

docs.title: Plant-Microbe Interactions in Livestock Systems
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2024 - Present Funding: [Funding Agency]

Investigating the role of plant endophytes in livestock nutrition and health outcomes.

Objectives:

  • Map endophytic communities in forage crops
  • Assess metabolic contributions of endophytes
  • Evaluate impacts on animal microbiome

Team Members: [Names]

docs.title: Evolutionary Genomics of Holobionts
docs.text:
Ongoing Project

Duration: 2022 - Present Funding: Max Planck Society

Using comparative genomics and metagenomics to understand evolutionary adaptations in host-microbe associations.

Objectives:

  • Reconstruct evolutionary histories of symbiotic relationships
  • Identify genomic signatures of co-evolution
  • Develop bioinformatic tools for holobiont analysis

Team Members: [Names]

docs.text:

Code: [Course Code] Semester: Fall Credits: 3

Topics:

  • Microbial diversity and phylogeny
  • Community assembly and succession
  • Microbial interactions
  • Biogeochemical cycling
  • Methods in microbial ecology

docs.title: Bioinformatics for Microbiome Research
docs.text:
Course Information

Code: [Course Code] Semester: Spring Credits: 3

Hands-on training in computational methods for analyzing microbiome sequencing data.

Topics:

  • Linux command line basics
  • Sequence quality control
  • Amplicon data analysis (QIIME2, DADA2)
  • Metagenomic analysis
  • Statistical methods for microbiome data
  • Data visualization in R

Prerequisites: Basic statistics, introductory biology

docs.title: Prof. Alejando Caro-Quintero
docs.text:
Position: Assistant Professor of Biology Department Email: acaroq@unal.edu.co Office: Building, Room 123

Bio: I am an assistant professor in the Department of Biology at the National University of Colombia (Bogotá). I have a degree in microbiology from the Universidad de los Andes, a master's degree from the University of Puerto Rico Recinto Universitario de Mayaguez (UPRM) and a PhD from the Georgia Institute of Techonology (GeorgiaTech). My research focuses on understanding the mechanisms that determine the diversity patterns of microbial communities associated with systems of agricultural and livestock importance, as well as elucidating through genomics and metagenomics the evolutionary adaptations that lead to the strengthening of these associations (e.g., plant endophytes).
